Description: Dancig girl's girdle with 10 pendant iron cones attached to the front, together with an iron ring; made of hippopotamus leather.
Curator's comments: Slip: "The Nouaer, central Africa" See John Petherick, Egypt, the Soudan and Central Africa, 1861, p.392: (on Af.2839 and 2845.a-b) (on the Dinkas) ‘The girls wear exceedingly pretty ornaments in the shape of an iron fringe round the waist, composed of a series of small hollow cones, polished like steel, closely strung on a leather thong, the centre being about four inches in length, gradually diminishing until at the back they are half that size. Relieved by the black skin of their wearers, they have a good effect, and, being highly prized, they descend as heirlooms from mother to daughter; and poor indeed is the girl who does not possess one.’
